newsitem.title: USA: Netscape says sees no pricing pressure.
newsitem.headline: Netscape says sees no pricing pressure.

text.p: Netscape Communications Corp executives said they have not been experiencing price pressure on either their server software or their Navigator browser and reiterated their focus on corporate Intranets.

"We are not experiencing any price pressure of late," Quincy Smith, manager of investor relations and business development, told investors in answer to analyst questions after a presentation to a Montgomery Securities Conference.
Mike Homer, senior vice president of marketing, told reporters later there had been no price pressure on either server or browser software.

Homer was responding to questions about a major company's statements at the conference earlier in the week that the Netscape Navigator browser software could be bought by corporate customers at $2 to $5 a copy, compared with retail prices around $40 a copy and a $49.95 suggested price.

Homer said the company does not discuss individual customers or pricing deals, but added that it would not be unreasonable for a browser site license on the order of $1 million for up to 300,000 users as part of an overall deal, noting it sells its software as a package to big customers.
As such, Netscape's products provide a broad range of features at prices well below competing products, such as International Business Machines Corp's Lotus Notes, or Microsoft Corp's back office.
